knownDisabilities: Parent of a child with profound physical disabilities and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); work addresses disability, caregiving, and grief.
keyWorks: And Yet We Rise: A Tale of Coping, Overcoming, and Transcending, graphic novel, 2017

knownDisabilities: Deafness / profound hearing loss; incorporates her experience of being deaf into her painting practice.
keyWorks: Modern fresco watercolor portrait series on clay panels (2000s–present)

knownDisabilities: None documented for the artist; key works focus on women who have undergone mastectomy for breast cancer and on aging bodies.
keyWorks: Wonders of Life, 2022

knownDisabilities: None documented; photographic practice centers disabled, intersex, and non-normative bodies and cadavers.
keyWorks: Gambler (1986), Portrait of Greg Vaughan (2004), Feast of Fools (1990)

knownDisabilities: Lived with severe depression and mental illness; her work often engages marginalized and disabled subjects.
keyWorks: Mexican Dwarf (aka Cha Cha) in His Hotel Room (1970); Jewish Giant at Home with His Parents in the Bronx, N.Y. (1970)
source: Ann Millett-Gallant, The Disabled Body in Contemporary Art; http://www.artnet.com/artists/diane-arbus/

knownDisabilities: Born with spina bifida; disabled artist and portraitist.
keyWorks: Tekki Lomnicki (1999) from the Circle Stories portrait series
source: Ann Millett-Gallant, The Disabled Body in Contemporary Art; https://www.rivalehrerart.com/

knownDisabilities: Childhood polio and catastrophic bus accident at 18 leading to spinal, pelvic, and leg injuries and lifelong pain and disability.
keyWorks: Self-Portrait with Cropped Hair (1940); What the Water Gave Me (1938); Two Nudes in a Forest (1939)

knownDisabilities: Dwarfism (little person); photographic work and self-representation as a disabled subject.
keyWorks: Johann's Kiss (1999); Bird (1999); Mannequins (1999–2003)
source: Ann Millett-Gallant, The Disabled Body in Contemporary Art; https://scholarspace.manoa.hawaii.edu/bitstream/10125/58395/1/686.pdf

knownDisabilities: None documented; her series Peter's World centers her brother Peter, who has Down syndrome.
keyWorks: Peter's World (1985–2005), photographic series of the artist’s brother Peter
source: Susan Harbage Page & Ann Millett-Gallant, “Artists and Muses: ‘Peter’s World’ and Other Photographs,” in Disability and Art History; https://susanharbagepage.com/

knownDisabilities: None documented; philosopher and critic of contemporary transgressive art involving disability and the body.
keyWorks: Aftershock: The Ethics of Contemporary Transgressive Art (2009)
source: Ann Millett-Gallant & Elizabeth Howie, Disability and Art History; https://www.bloomsbury.com/us/aftershock-9781845115241/

knownDisabilities: None documented; create works featuring disabled subjects, including depictions of Stephen Hawking.
keyWorks: Sculpture Übermensch (portrait of Stephen Hawking), 1995
source: Referenced in Disability and Art History; various exhibition catalogues

knownDisabilities: Parkinson's disease (diagnosed in the early 1950s), leading to progressive disability and multiple brain surgeries.
keyWorks: You Have Seen Their Faces (with Erskine Caldwell, 1937); photographic essays for LIFE magazine

knownDisabilities: None documented; LIFE photographer whose work includes images of disabled children.
keyWorks: Nine-Year-Old Neil Koenigm, Who Has Cerebral Palsy, Walking Unassisted (1950), LIFE magazine photo essay

knownDisabilities: None documented; curator whose exhibition included images of disabled people and disabled veterans.
keyWorks: The Family of Man exhibition (1955, Museum of Modern Art, New York)
source: MoMA, The Family of Man exhibition catalogue

knownDisabilities: None documented; photojournalist whose work focuses on mentally disabled children among other social issues.
keyWorks: Photographic essay Retarded Children (Life, October 18, 1954); book Retarded Children Can Be Helped (1957)

knownDisabilities: None documented; Magnum photographer whose Circus series portrays a dwarf clown and other disabled circus performers.
keyWorks: The Dwarf, Jimmy Armstrong, Circus (1958) from the Circus series

knownDisabilities: None documented; street photographer whose work includes images of disabled veterans and American social life.
keyWorks: American Legion Convention, Dallas, Texas (1964)
source: Mary Warner Marien, 100 Ideas That Changed Photography; Fraenkel Gallery, San Francisco

knownDisabilities: Congenital limb difference: born with two fingers on each hand and two toes on each foot; identifies as a disabled artist and disability culture worker.
keyWorks: Crip Couture (2011–ongoing) wearable art series; disability-fashion body adornments exhibited internationally

knownDisabilities: None documented; work obsessively represents fragmented, dismembered, or doll-like bodies that intersect with discourses of disability and the abject.
keyWorks: Die Puppe (The Doll) series, mid-1930s
source: Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Doll; surrealism/surrealist sculpture scholarship

knownDisabilities: Visual impairment later in life; some scholarship discusses his late-life vision issues in relation to disability and seeing.
keyWorks: Making Human Junk (1914) child-labor poster; photographs of workers with postural deformities, scoliosis, and other disabilities (early 1900s)
source: The Routledge Companion to Art and Disability; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lewis_Hine

knownDisabilities: Born without arms (bilateral upper-limb amelia); Irish performance and visual artist.
keyWorks: Self-portrait nude posing performances; featured in the documentary Vital Signs: Crip Culture Talks Back (1996)

knownDisabilities: Visual disability / eye problems in later life that limited his ability to produce detailed trompe-l’œil works.
keyWorks: A Bachelor's Drawer (c. 1890–1894); The Slate (c. 1895)
source: The Routledge Companion to Art and Disability; https://udspace.udel.edu/items/ddc768eb-489f-47fa-8046-1aefa63aa932; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Haberle

knownDisabilities: None documented; sculpture Eternal Youth has been analyzed as embodying fascist ideals of the 'able body' and eugenic beauty.
keyWorks: Eternal Youth (Rockefeller Center, New York)
source: Rockefeller Center Archives; Disability and Art History scholarship on fascist aesthetics

knownDisabilities: None documented; public sculptures such as those at Chieti and Ragusa express fascist-era ideals of the strong, able-bodied citizen.
keyWorks: Monumental sculptures at Chieti and Ragusa (1930s)
source: National Archive of the Netherlands, Willem van de Poll Photo Collection

knownDisabilities: None documented for the artist; his memorial sculpture represents Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who used a wheelchair due to a paralytic illness commonly attributed to polio.
keyWorks: Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial (Washington, D.C.), including FDR in a wheelchair
source: U.S. National Park Service (NPS) documentation; NPS/Victoria Stauffenberg photo credit

knownDisabilities: Bilateral upper-limb amelia (born without arms); appears as a key figure in crip culture media and disability-arts documentaries.
keyWorks: Appearance and interview in Vital Signs: Crip Culture Talks Back (1996) and other disability-arts media
source: Vital Signs: Crip Culture Talks Back (documentary); https://adiarts.ie/artists/showcasing/meet-

knownDisabilities: Depression; long-term mental health struggles; died by suicide in 1971.
keyWorks: Child with a Toy Hand Grenade in Central Park, N.Y.C., 1962; A Jewish giant at home with his parents in the Bronx, N.Y.C., 1970; Photographic series of marginalized subjects including people with physical and mental disabilities, 1960s.

knownDisabilities: No documented disability; The Lord is My Shepherd (1926) depicts elderly Deaf neighbors from the Martha’s Vineyard Deaf community, associated with local sign language use.
keyWorks: The Lord is My Shepherd, 1926 (portrait of Deaf couple George and Sabrina West from the Chilmark Deaf community on Martha’s Vineyard).

knownDisabilities: No documented disability; Übermensch (Portrait of Stephen Hawking) represents physicist Stephen Hawking, who had amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and used a wheelchair.
keyWorks: Übermensch (Portrait of Stephen Hawking), 1995.

knownDisabilities: Cerebral palsy and chronic illness-related access needs; disabled artist whose work focuses on fatigue, mobility, and accessibility in public and museum spaces.
keyWorks: Do you want us here or not, 2018–ongoing (bench series about museum accessibility); Crip Time, ongoing text- and furniture-based works; The only thing I like about stairs is that they can be a place to sit in a pinch, c. 2021.

knownDisabilities: Progressive hearing loss beginning in childhood; Deaf/hard-of-hearing artist reflecting on communication, sensory loss, and language.
keyWorks: Wha_ i_ I _old you a __ory in a language I _an _ear, 2014 (video work reciting a poem first normally and then only the sounds she can hear).

artist: Barton Cooke Hirst and George Arthur Piersol
knownDisabilities: Conjoined twins (ectopagus dicephalus dibrachius tripus) depicted: twin infants joined at the thorax with two heads, two upper limbs, and three lower limbs.
keyWorks: “Ectopagus” dicephalus dibrachius tripus twins, from Human Monstrosities, Part IV, c. 1891–1893; photograph later reproduced in “A Century of Medical Oddities,” Newsweek, January 7, 2008.

knownDisabilities: No documented disability; “Disability Chic” satirizes fashioning disability and the superficial use of disability imagery, and has been critiqued in disability-aesthetics scholarship.
keyWorks: “Disability Chic,” cartoon published in New York Press, February 2–11, 1998.

knownDisabilities: No known disability; Les Menottes de cuivre reconfigures the classical female body (after the Venus de Milo) into a fragmented, partly flesh-colored figure often cited in disability-aesthetics discussions.
keyWorks: Les menottes de cuivre (Copper Handcuffs), 1931 (or 1930s), painted sculpture based on the Venus de Milo, Royal Museums of Fine Arts of Belgium, Brussels.

knownDisabilities: No documented disability; Disabled Workers depicts physically disabled industrial workers and veterans in post–World War I Germany.
keyWorks: Disabled Workers, 1922, drawing/print representing injured laborers (Art Institute of Chicago).

knownDisabilities: No documented disability; Les Deux Baigneuses is frequently discussed in relation to disability aesthetics and the fragmentary/classical body (in dialogue with works like the Venus de Milo).
keyWorks: Les Deux Baigneuses ou Dina de dos et de profil, 1938, oil on canvas, Fondation Dina Vierny–Musée Maillol, Paris.

knownDisabilities: Transverse myelitis leading to permanent hemiparesis and partial paralysis; uses braces, crutches, and an electric wheelchair; openly identifies as a disabled artist.
keyWorks: The Swing (after Fragonard), 2001; Nelson’s Ship in a Bottle, 2010; recurrent use of headless or constrained figures in Dutch wax fabric exploring race, class, empire, and embodied limitation.

knownDisabilities: Severe spinal injuries and broken back from a 1960 construction accident; was paralyzed from the waist/hips down for several years and used a wheelchair, leg braces, and crutches; later had a leg amputated after a welding injury.
keyWorks: Are Years What? (for Marianne Moore), 1967; large-scale crane-built steel sculptures produced after his accident that reimagine sculptural labor with disability.

knownDisabilities: Deaf since birth; primary language is American Sign Language (ASL); her practice explicitly centers Deaf culture and communication barriers.
keyWorks: Degrees of Deaf Rage in Everyday Situations, 2018; Close Readings, 2015; The Sound of… drawing series, 2017–ongoing; works derived from her ASL performance of the U.S. national anthem at Super Bowl LIV, 2020.

knownDisabilities: Serious mental illness with episodes of psychosis, depression, self-harm, and hospitalization; historical debates include possible epilepsy and other neuropsychiatric diagnoses.
keyWorks: Self-Portrait with Bandaged Ear, 1889; The Starry Night, 1889; Wheatfield with Crows, 1890.

knownDisabilities: Profound deafness following a severe, undiagnosed illness around 1793, accompanied by vertigo, headaches, and hallucinations; lived and worked as a Deaf artist for the last decades of his life.
keyWorks: Los Caprichos print series, 1797–1798 (including The Sleep of Reason Produces Monsters); Black Paintings, c. 1819–1823 (such as Saturn Devouring His Son and other works reflecting his post-illness outlook).

knownDisabilities: No known disability; Blind (Les Aveugles) centers people born blind describing their ‘image of beauty’ and juxtaposes their portraits with text and photographs of what they describe.
keyWorks: Blind (Les Aveugles / The Blind) series, 1986, including works such as Blind #14 and The Blind No. 11 “Sheep are beautiful.”

knownDisabilities: Dyslexia; prosopagnosia (face blindness); spinal artery collapse in 1988 resulting in partial paralysis and long-term wheelchair use.
keyWorks: Big Self-Portrait, 1967–1968; Self-Portrait series, 1990s–2000s; large-scale gridded portraits created after his 1988 paralysis using a brush strapped to his wrist.

knownDisabilities: Multiple sclerosis, diagnosed in 2011; his practice reflects the impact of chronic illness on movement, perception, and architectural space.
keyWorks: Sculptural and installation works in clay, metal, polymer glass, and natural materials exploring body, memory, and landscape (ongoing).

knownDisabilities: Down syndrome; congenital deafness; labeled as having an intellectual disability and nonverbal; institutionalized for decades before beginning to make art at Creative Growth.
keyWorks: Untitled fiber-wrapped sculptures created 1988–2005 using found objects bound with yarn, twine, and fabric (Creative Growth Art Center corpus).

knownDisabilities: Autism (autistic savant); considered legally blind after cataract surgery; described as having significant visual impairment from childhood.
keyWorks: Large-scale wax crayon landscapes and seascapes, 1960s–2000s (over 4,000 drawings), including Scottish and European coastal scenes collected internationally.

knownDisabilities: Severe illness and abdominal cancer in 1941; major surgery left him largely bedridden and using a wheelchair for the last decade of his life.
keyWorks: Jazz (cut-out book), 1947; Blue Nude II, 1952; late cut-out series created while working from bed or wheelchair (‘painting with scissors’).

knownDisabilities: Bone disease and childhood fractures that stunted leg growth, leaving him of short stature with significant mobility impairment; often linked to genetic disorder (e.g., pycnodysostosis) and complicated by alcoholism.
keyWorks: At the Moulin Rouge, 1892–1895; posters for the Moulin Rouge and other Parisian cabarets, 1890s, depicting nightlife from the vantage point of a disabled artist.

knownDisabilities: Progressive bilateral cataracts beginning in his 60s; underwent cataract surgery and wore tinted lenses, with significant impact on color perception and his late painting style. Visual Blindess.
keyWorks: Water Lilies (Nymphéas) series, c. 1897–1926; late Giverny pond paintings made while coping with cataract-impaired vision.
